description: A stout pole with a large mace head attached to the end with a chain, a purpose-made combat version of the peasant flail.  It specializes in threshing people in metal armor, rather than grain.
A short pole with a spiked steel ball attached to it by a chain.
A stout pole with a wooden club attached to the end with a leather cord.  This farming tool was historically used to thresh grain, but was frequently pressed into service as a weapon.
A weapon originating from East Asia consisting of a pair of short sticks connected by a shorter rope or chain.  The design is a bit unwieldy, but fast and deadly in the right hands.
A long spool of chain with a steel weight at one end.  What a terrible night it'll be for anyone who gets hit by this thing.
A two-handed war club used in feudal Japan by samurai against armored opponents, it's made from hardwood studded with metal.
A sturdy wooden cudgel once essential to the great American pastime.
An aluminum version of the tapered club used to play baseball.  It's lighter, stronger, and more durable than the wooden variety.
A baseball bat made of foam rubber with a plastic handle.  Light and easy to wield, but almost completely ineffective if your goal is to hurt someone.
A telescoping baton.  Right now, it's collapsed for easy storage.  Activate to expand.
A telescoping baton that's extended and ready to bust some heads.  Activate to collapse.

An axe designed for medieval warfare, the head secured to the haft with langets.  Though formidable, it's lighter than the sort you'd use for felling trees, and would make an inferior tool for that purpose.
A dull, cheaply-made replica of a huge axe designed for warfare.
A huge axe designed for warfare.  Or it would be, but the axe heads aren't seated properly at all.

A short, easily concealed bludgeoning weapon consisting of a weight embedded at the end of a short leather shaft.  Formerly used by law enforcement, this weapon is meant to stun or knock out the subject, although head strikes have a high risk of causing a permanent, disabling brain injury or being fatal.
A solid wood training katana, exactingly crafted to mimic the weight and balance of the real thing.  Despite its lack of a sharp metal edge, it's still quite capable as a blunt weapon.
A standard bowling pin.  This could make a decent weapon, if it came to that.
A baseball bat wrapped with barbed wire, giving it a little extra oomph without compromising its durability.
A walking stick designed to lean on, whether for mobility assistance or puttin' on the ritz.
A sinister looking cane made of plastic.  It has a shiny red orb gripped by claws at the handle.

variants.description: A sinister looking cane made of plastic.  It has a shiny red orb gripped by claws at the handle.
A plastic cane designed to look like a wizard's staff.  They shall not pass!
A plastic cane festooned with ribbons and glitter.

description: An aluminum rod with a brace and padding designed to help support the body using the arm.  It could be combined with another like it, or used on its own.
A pair of aluminum rods with a brace and padding designed to help support the body using the arms.  These would make for an abysmal weapon, but they'd help you get around on a broken leg.
A wooden rod with a brace designed to help support the body using the arm.  It could be combined with another like it, or used on its own.
A pair of wooden rods with a brace designed to help support the body using the arms.  These would make for an abysmal weapon, but they'd help you get around on a broken leg.
A pair of rods, one wood and one aluminum, with braces designed to help support the body using the arms.  These would make for an abysmal weapon, but they'd help you get around on a broken leg.
Mankind's oldest weapon: a length of wood tapered slightly to maximize weight at the business end.  In other words, a club.
A length of wood with nails driven through the business end to create a menacing, if inelegant, weapon.
A thin aluminum rod with a heavy head on one end for hitting golf balls.  It looks quite fragile, but it could do a fair bit of damage before the shaft got too bent.
A heavy steel head on a long shaft, designed for demolition work.  It's a very hard-hitting melee weapon, but slow to swing and will probably exhaust you quickly.
A stout and hefty hammer, more akin to a mini sledge than a claw or ball-peen.  It's useful for portable demolition work, but unwieldy as a weapon.
A curved wooden stick with with a flat paddle at one end, commonly used by hockey players.
A flat wooden club with sharpened flakes of stone, ceramic, or glass stuck to both sides, a reasonable facsimile of the weapons once used by Aztec warriors.
A flat wooden club with impossibly-sharp teeth stuck to both sides, a postapocalyptic facsimile of the weapons once used by Aztec warriors.
A modern reimagining of the ancient Aztec weapon, made of a flat wooden club inset along its edges with steel razor blades.
A long wooden staff reinforced with steel langets and ferrules.
A medieval hammer with a spike on one end, made for battle.  Its odd shape and balance make it an excellent weapon, but an ineffective tool.
A versatile polearm with a spiked hammer head, a spike, and a hook attached to a beefy wooden pole.
A cheap piece of crap imitation of a versatile polearm with a spiked hammer head, probably meant to be used for LARPing.
A medieval weapon consisting of a wooden handle with a metal head.  It's lighter than it looks.
//: Lighter and more accurate than the morning star.

description: A light, cheaply-made replica of a medieval weapon that would normally consist of a wood handle with a heavy metal head.
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy metal head.  The head feels a bit loose.
Two steel pipes fitted end-to-end in a clumsy facsimile of a quarterstaff.
While nothing more than a lump of bronze on a stick, it is still surprisingly effective.

A large hammer, forged from the heart of a dying star.  It bears the inscription:

Whosoever holds this hammer,
If he be worthy,
Shall possess the power to‚Ä¶
CRUSH!'
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.  It is bigger and heavier than a typical mace, and its spikes can deal serious damage to soft targets.
A light, cheaply-made replica of a medieval weapon that would normally consist of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.
A medieval weapon consisting of a wood handle with a heavy, spiked metal ball on the end.  The weight feels off on this one, and the spikes are blunted.
A baseball bat with several nails driven through it.  This might help it open some bleeding wounds, but at some cost to durability.
A plank of wood with several nails through one end; essentially a simple mace.  It's hard to hold onto, but capable of doing some damage.
A hardwood stick designed for hitting colorful balls around a felt table.  Truly, the coolest of sports.
//1: This assumes the pool cue is a cylinder with the length from the Amazon listing and the diameter of 30mm as Google said it is a likely diameter if the pin is 13mm.

description: A long, thin stick carved smooth for an easy grip.  These are commonly used by hikers to help navigate steep slopes, and could serve as a fighting staff, though this one looks too thin to last for long.
A fighting staff carved out of wood.  Lightweight and good for defense, it is surprisingly easy to handle.
A wooden staff weapon used in Okinawan martial arts.  It has been finely sanded and treated with oil for integrity.
A pair of nested socks with a stone tied inside.  A true weapon of desperation.

A stout, knotty stick with a large knob at the top that has been left to cure in a chimney.  A traditional Irish weapon, the shillelagh was originally used for settling disputes in a gentlemanly manner.

A stout knotty stick with a large knob at the top that has been left to cure in a chimney.  A traditional Irish weapon, the shillelagh was originally used for settling disputes in a gentlemanly manner.  The knob has been hollowed and filled with molten heavy metal to pack more of a punch.
A curved wooden club with a ball head carved from a root burl.  These devastating weapons were once used by indigenous peoples across North America.
A curved wooden club cradling a stone head.  These devastating weapons were once used by indigenous peoples across North America.

An ironshod quarterstaff that has a high-voltage stun gun built into the handle.  The stun gun is wired to the metal caps at either end of the staff, allowing you to zap a dangerous opponent should beating them senseless with it prove too hazardous.

A reinforced plastic tonfa; the core is filled with capacitors and a high-yield rechargeable storage battery.  When a switch on the handle is pressed, a high-voltage current is transmitted to the two electrodes mounted in the end of the tonfa, and by extension to anyone unfortunate enough to be in contact with them.  It also has a nifty flashlight, which is off at the moment.

A reinforced plastic tonfa; the core is filled with capacitors and a high-yield rechargeable storage battery.  When a switch on the handle is pressed, a high-voltage current is transmitted to the two electrodes mounted in the end of the weapon, and by extension to anyone unfortunate enough to be in contact with them.  The integral flashlight is turned on, continually draining power and lighting the surrounding area.
A hard plastic truncheon commonly employed by police.  Originally an Okinawan weapon, it consists of a stick with a perpendicular handle attached a third of the way down its length.
A stout wooden truncheon of the sort commonly employed by police.  Originally an Okinawan weapon, it consists of a stick with a perpendicular handle attached a third of the way down its length.
A large street sign, its aluminum pole uprooted.  An unreasonably strong person might be able to wield it like a crude axe.
